Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied warranty of habitability and a covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This is a concurring/dissenting opinion that agrees the old no-repair rule should be abandoned and that some implied obligation tied to code compliance should exist, but it explicitly *disagrees* with the majority’s broader formulation of an implied warranty of habitability and instead proposes an implied covenant limited to statutory and regulatory minimum standards. It does not discuss or recognize an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment as such. Thus, this portion of the case is not good authority for the broad proposition that every Massachusetts residential tenancy includes both an implied warranty of habitability and a covenant of quiet enjoyment, and in fact questions the majority’s chosen doctrinal route on habitability.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s failure to correct the unsanitary and unsafe condition of mold in the bathroom, after notice, constitutes a breach of her statutory and common-law obligations to maintain habitable premises and not to interfere with Plaintiff’s covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case is not about mold, but it directly addresses when a landlord’s failure to correct defective or unsafe conditions after notice constitutes a violation of statutory quiet enjoyment and habitability obligations. The SJC explains that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair defects of which the landlord has notice (including conditions making an apartment uninhabitable or unsafe) is actionable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and common-law habitability. By analogy, an unsanitary and unsafe mold condition left uncorrected after notice falls squarely within this principle.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass.raw_text: Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass.proposition: Mold conditions of the type described are recognized as conditions that may endanger or materially impair the health or safety of occupants and thus constitute interference with quiet enjoyment when the landlord, after notice, fails or refuses to remedy them.
Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss mold, air quality, or similar conditions, nor does it analyze what types of conditions can endanger or materially impair health or safety for purposes of quiet enjoyment. The case finds breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment based on lack of heat, rodent and cockroach infestations, and other defects, but the quiet enjoyment claim is not elaborated and no principle specific to mold is stated. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that mold conditions of a described type constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment when unremedied after notice.
Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “During her tenancy, she and her two sons endured continuing infestations of rodents and cockroaches. Heat in the apartment ranged from nonexistent (at worst) to insufficient (at best). Cruz Management had notice of these defects, as well as others, which the judge found existed, but which he did not specifically describe.… Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Mold conditions of the type described are recognized as conditions that may endanger or materially impair the health or safety of occupants and thus constitute interference with quiet enjoyment when the landlord, after notice, fails or refuses to remedy them.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case concerns noise from a lounge constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, not mold or other health-related environmental conditions. While it stands for the broader principle that a landlord’s failure to remedy conditions within their control that substantially interfere with habitability can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically address mold or recognize mold conditions as endangering health or safety. Thus it is too specific a proposition for this opinion to support directly.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a landlord’s failure to remedy serious and recurring conditions that endanger or materially impair the health or safety of a tenant, after notice, constitutes an “indirect interference” with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that a landlord’s failure, after notice, to take reasonable measures to remove persons engaged in unlawful and dangerous activity on the premises can constitute a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It characterizes such a failure as ‘permitting’ a condition that substantially interferes with the tenancy, which fits the notion of an indirect interference with quiet enjoyment when serious safety-threatening conditions are allowed to persist. The opinion reverses summary judgment precisely to allow tenants to prove this theory at trial.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment. We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment is read broadly to protect tenants from serious interferences with the character and value of their tenancy, including conditions of disrepair and code violations that the landlord fails or refuses to correct.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court expressly interprets the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment in G.L. c. 186, § 14 by drawing on the common-law meaning of “quiet enjoyment” as freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises, and applies it to repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions. It confirms that interference with quiet enjoyment can be based on a landlord’s acts or omissions that violate sanitary code duties and maintain uninhabitable, flood-prone conditions, and it allows recovery of “actual and consequential” damages (including personal injuries) when the landlord fails or refuses to correct such conditions. Although the quiet enjoyment damages award is vacated as duplicative, the opinion squarely endorses a broad, tenant-protective reading of the statutory covenant encompassing serious disrepair and code violations.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes… [W]e hold that… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s conduct is likewise inconsistent with the implied warranty of habitability and the requirements of the State Sanitary Code, and such code violations and habitability defects are recognized bases for finding a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly ties the implied warranty of habitability to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and recognizes rent abatement as a remedy when there are substantial Sanitary Code violations. However, it does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment at all, nor does it state that such code violations or habitability defects constitute a violation of that covenant. The case therefore supports the first part of the proposition (habitability/Code) but not the claimed link to a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts enforce the mandatory nature of at least three months’ rent as damages upon proof of a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, irrespective of the precise dollar value of proven actual damages.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872\u.support_reasoning: The opinion in Haddad v. Gonzalez concerns emotional distress and warranty-of-habitability damages and the computation of treble damages under G.L. c. 93A; it does not analyze or apply the statutory minimum-damages formula of G.L. c. 186, § 14. There is no discussion of three months’ rent as mandatory damages under § 14, nor any indication that damages under § 14 were awarded or calculated irrespective of actual damages. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about § 14’s three-months’ rent remedy.
